groups.description: Guidelines for naming and formatting page titles in the spider project

requirements.description: Use scientific names for article titles unless the common name is well-known or reasonably unique.
requirements.reference: Scientific names should be used for the article titles unless the common name is well-known or reasonably unique.
requirements.when: When creating or editing article titles

requirements.description: Use Latin names for article titles below family level, with exceptions.
requirements.reference: Below family, Latin names are almost always used for article titles, though there are exceptions.
requirements.when: When creating or editing article titles below family level

requirements.description: Capitalize but do not italicize family titles and higher taxa.
requirements.reference: Family titles and higher taxa are capitalized, but not italicized.
requirements.when: When formatting family titles and higher taxa

requirements.description: Italicize and capitalize genera titles.
requirements.reference: Genera titles are always both italicized and capitalized.
requirements.when: When formatting genera titles

requirements.description: Italicize and capitalize species titles, including both genera and species.
requirements.reference: Species titles should be both italicized and capitalized, and include both the genera and species.
requirements.when: When formatting species titles

requirements.description: Use lowercase and non-italicized format for common names as titles.
requirements.reference: Common names as titles are lowercase and not italicized.
requirements.when: When using common names as titles

requirements.description: Use sentence case for spider common names.
requirements.reference: Use sentence case for spider common names (rather than title case).
requirements.when: When writing spider common names in text

groups.description: Guidelines for marking stub articles in spider taxonomy

requirements.description: All mainspace articles must have a short description.
requirements.reference: All mainspace articles should have a short description.
requirements.when: When creating or editing mainspace articles

requirements.description: Short descriptions should normally be limited to 'genus of spiders'.
requirements.reference: Short descriptions should normally be limited to 'genus of spiders'.
requirements.when: When writing short descriptions for genus articles

requirements.description: Include the commonly known and unambiguous English name of the family in the short description if applicable.
requirements.reference: If the family has a commonly known and unambiguous English name, it can also be included.
requirements.when: When the family has a commonly known and unambiguous English name

requirements.description: Use a layered template for entering range information into a world map.
requirements.reference: It's easiest to work with a layered template for entering range information into a world map.
requirements.when: When creating or editing distribution maps

requirements.description: Use pure green (#00FF00) for range information on distribution maps.
requirements.reference: At the moment, pure green (#00FF00, (0,255,0)) is used.
requirements.when: When adding range information to distribution maps

requirements.description: Be general rather than specific when stating numbers of genera and species.
requirements.reference: Thus, it is a good idea to be general rather than specific: e.g. stating 'contains around 80 genera and 600 species' rather than 'contains 79 genera and 587 species'.
requirements.when: When stating numbers of genera and species

requirements.description: Consider adding a spider stub template to articles lacking information.
requirements.reference: If you think an article is not yet useful for most people due to it lacking information, consider adding one of the spider stub templates to the end of the article.
requirements.when: When an article is not yet useful due to lack of information

requirements.description: Use categories at Spider stubs to find possible stub templates.
requirements.reference: The categories at [[:Category:Spider stubs]] provide a list of possible stub templates.
requirements.when: When looking for stub templates

groups.description: Guidelines for marking talk pages in the spider project

requirements.description: Every page of a species, genus, subfamily, or other clearly defined taxonomical grouping must have a taxobox.
requirements.reference: Every page of a species, genus, subfamily, or other clearly defined taxonomical grouping should have a taxobox.
requirements.where: Species, genus, subfamily, or other taxonomical grouping pages
requirements.when: When creating or editing these pages

requirements.description: Choose the most useful picture for identifying the species in a species-level taxobox.
requirements.reference: When choosing a picture to use for a species-level taxobox, choose the picture that would be most useful for identifying the species.
requirements.when: When selecting images for species-level taxoboxes

requirements.description: Include images of both males and females in the taxobox if they are significantly different.
requirements.reference: Males and females are often significantly different; if so, try to find an image of each.
requirements.when: When males and females of the species are significantly different

requirements.description: List synonyms in the taxobox with a reference.
requirements.reference: It's useful to list the synonyms in the taxobox. A reference should also be provided.
requirements.when: When listing synonyms in the taxobox

requirements.description: Use the Specieslist template to format a list of species names.
requirements.reference: The {{tl|Specieslist}} template provides an easy way to format a list of species names.
requirements.when: When formatting a list of species names

requirements.description: Automatically italicize species names and use small text for the authority in the synonyms list.
requirements.reference: The synonyms will then be listed as below, with automatic italicization for the species name and small text for the authority.
requirements.when: When displaying synonyms in the taxobox

requirements.description: Use the World Spider Catalog as a source for synonyms, but interpret the data.
requirements.reference: The World Spider Catalog can be used as a source of synonyms, but interpretation is needed because it gives a list of taxonomic references, not synonyms.
requirements.when: When sourcing synonyms from the World Spider Catalog

requirements.description: Do not list the currently accepted name under 'Synonyms' in the taxobox.
requirements.reference: However this is the currently accepted name, so isn't listed under 'Synonyms' in the taxobox.
requirements.when: When determining which names to list under synonyms

requirements.description: Do not include misidentifications as synonyms.
requirements.reference: 'Conaranea gertschi' is not a junior synonym, but a misidentification.
requirements.when: When identifying synonyms

requirements.description: Repetitions of the same binomen are never synonyms.
requirements.reference: Repetitions of the same binomen are never synonyms.
requirements.when: When listing synonyms

requirements.description: Use a taxonomic category for all ranks, typically the family category.
requirements.reference: For all ranks, use a 'taxonomic category', typically the family category.
requirements.when: When categorizing articles about spider taxa

requirements.description: Use genus category for large genera.
requirements.reference: For large genera, use the genus category.
requirements.when: When categorizing large genera

requirements.description: Use specific categories for families and genera.
requirements.reference: For families and genera, use the category for that rank of taxon.
requirements.when: When categorizing families and genera

requirements.description: Use monotypic genera category for monotypic genera.
requirements.reference: For monotypic genera, use e.g. [Category:Monotypic Araneomorphae genera].
requirements.when: When categorizing monotypic genera

requirements.description: Use 'Spiders described in YEAR' category for species.
requirements.reference: For species, also use a 'Spiders described in YEAR' category.
requirements.when: When categorizing species

requirements.description: Do not use 'Spiders described in YEAR' categories for other ranks.
requirements.reference: Do not use these categories for other ranks, because ultimately they are subcategories of 'Species described in YEAR'.
requirements.when: When categorizing ranks other than species

requirements.description: Add a 'location' category for species and optionally for narrowly endemic genera and families.
requirements.reference: For species, and optionally for narrowly endemic genera and families, add a 'location' category.
requirements.when: When categorizing species and narrowly endemic taxa

requirements.description: Place Pholcidae in the Pholcidae and Araneomorphae families categories.
requirements.reference: [[Pholcidae]] is placed in [[:Category:Pholcidae]] and [[:Category:Araneomorphae families]].
requirements.when: When categorizing Pholcidae

requirements.description: Place Orb-weaver spider in the Araneidae category and its redirect in both Araneidae and Araneomorphae families categories.
requirements.reference: [[Orb-weaver spider]] is placed in [[:Category:Araneidae]]. The redirect at {{-r|Araneidae}} is also placed in [[:Category:Araneidae]] but also in [[:Category:Araneomorphae families]].
requirements.when: When categorizing Orb-weaver spider and its redirect

requirements.description: Place Araneus in the Araneus and Araneomorphae genera categories.
requirements.reference: ''[[Araneus]]'' is placed in [[:Category:Araneus]] (a large genus, so used instead of the family as the main taxonomic category), and [[:Category:Araneomorphae genera]].
requirements.when: When categorizing Araneus

requirements.description: Place Araneus diadematus in the Araneus, Spiders described in 1758, and Holarctic spiders categories.
requirements.reference: ''[[Araneus diadematus]]'' is placed in [[:Category:Araneus]] (a large genus, so used instead of the family as the main taxonomic category), [[:Category:Spiders described in 1758]] and [[:Category:Holarctic spiders]] (the appropriate largest area category is always used).
requirements.when: When categorizing Araneus diadematus

requirements.description: Place Barn spider in the Araneus and Spiders of North America categories, and its redirect in Araneus and Spiders described in 1882 categories.
requirements.reference: [[Barn spider]] is placed in [[:Category:Araneus]] (a large genus, so used instead of the family as the main taxonomic category) and [[:Category: Spiders of North America]]. The redirect at the scientific name, ''{{-r|Araneus cavaticus}}'', is also placed in [[:Category:Araneus]] but additionally in [[:Category:Spiders described in 1882]].
requirements.when: When categorizing Barn spider and its redirect

requirements.description: Place the redirect Nita (spider) in the Pholcidae and Monotypic Araneomorphae genera categories, and Nita elsaff in Pholcidae, Spiders described in 2007, Spiders of Africa, and Spiders of Asia categories.
requirements.reference: The redirect {{-r|Nita (spider)|''Nita'' (spider)}} is placed in [[:Category:Pholcidae]] and [[:Category:Monotypic Araneomorphae genera]]. The article at ''[[Nita elsaff]]'' is placed in [[:Category:Pholcidae]], [[:Category:Spiders described in 2007]], [[:Category:Spiders of Africa]] and [[:Category:Spiders of Asia]].
requirements.when: When categorizing Nita (spider) and Nita elsaff

requirements.description: Enter the WikiProject Spiders template at the beginning of a talk page.
requirements.reference: At the beginning of a talk page enter this template: {{WikiProject Spiders|class=CLASS|importance=IMPORTANCE}} or {{WPSpiders|CLASS|IMPORTANCE}}
requirements.when: When creating or editing talk pages

requirements.description: Replace 'CLASS' and 'IMPORTANCE' with appropriate values in the WikiProject Spiders template.
requirements.reference: where the words in capital letters are replaced by appropriate values.
requirements.when: When using the WikiProject Spiders template

groups.description: Guidelines for citing archived web pages in spider articles

requirements.description: Do not add or remove parentheses in author citations for species.
requirements.reference: Don't add or remove parentheses in author citations for species as they have a precise meaning.
requirements.when: When citing authors for species

requirements.description: Provide a reference for the author citation, normally in the taxobox.
requirements.reference: A reference should always be given for the author citation (normally in the taxobox).
requirements.when: When including author citations

requirements.description: Use a reliable secondary source for author citations.
requirements.reference: A reliable secondary source is needed that says this is the accepted authority.
requirements.when: When verifying the accepted authority for author citations

requirements.description: Use the World Spider Catalog as the main secondary reference for authors of family, genus, and species names.
requirements.reference: The main secondary reference for the authors of family, genus and species names is the World Spider Catalog.
requirements.when: When referencing authors of family, genus, and species names

requirements.description: Use the List of Arachnologists to wikify the author of taxa.
requirements.reference: You can use the List of Arachnologists to easily wikify the author of taxa.
requirements.when: When wikifying the author of taxa

requirements.description: Enter authors found elsewhere into the List of Arachnologists.
requirements.reference: If you do find an author elsewhere, please enter it into the above list.
requirements.when: When an author is found outside the list

requirements.description: Include the year in parentheses behind the author's name in references.
requirements.reference: The year is in parentheses behind the author's name.
requirements.when: When formatting references

requirements.description: Italicize species, genera, and journal names in references.
requirements.reference: Species, genera and journal name are in italics.
requirements.when: When formatting references

requirements.description: Use tools to make citations in a standard output format.
requirements.reference: Tools make citations fairly easy, in a standard output format, and provide a checklist of items needed for each of type of citation.
requirements.when: When creating citations

requirements.description: Use Internet Archive's Way Back Machine for archived copies of web pages.
requirements.reference: If a URL dies, Internet Archive's Way Back Machine often contains archived copies of web pages that have gone offline.
requirements.when: When a URL is no longer accessible

requirements.description: Include accessdate, archiveurl, and archivedate parameters when citing archived copies.
requirements.reference: When citing archived copies: parameter accessdate= is still required, and you must also add parameter archiveurl=... for the link provided by Internet Archive (as well as the normal 'url=...'), and add parameter archivedate=... giving the date when the archived copy was made.
requirements.when: When citing archived web pages
